text.p: Following are the main stories in today's Malaysian newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

-- Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad opens the annual Langkawi International Dialogue, a get together of heads of states from various Asian and African countries to develop government private-sector partnerships. He urged participants to develop "Smart Partnership" that is based on sharing fairly and equally.
-- Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said the Anti-Corruption Bill 1997 would ensure that "big sharks" in the corruption would not escape conviction.
-- Malaysia is expected to sign next month a deal with Siemens AG to acquire railway units for the high-speed link between Kuala Lumpur and a new international airport about 70 km to the north.
-- Ann Joo Resources Bhd is planning to raise 546 million ringgit through a rights and a bonds issue to set up a mini steel mill.
-- Jasatera Bhd will launch three property development projects by September which will have a combined sales turnover of 303 million ringgit.

-- A consortium awarded the privatisation of state-owned railway service, KTM, will start becoming part of the management from from Friday, DRB-Hicom group chairman Salleh Sulong said. DRB-Hicom group is one of the three companies including Renong and Bolton Properties awarded the project.
-- The government aims to eradicate poverty by the year 2000, Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said.
